title: Argument over a missing pot plant led to a son destroying his sister's doll collection
text:
A man who flew into a violent rage and smashed up his mother's home, his sister's doll collection, and smashed a phone with a sledgehammer after he realised his pot plant was missing has walked away without a conviction.

Dylan Perry, 21, was visiting his mother's home in September when the Bundaberg local noticed a pot plant given to him by a dead relative was missing, News Mail reported.

Bundaberg Magistrates Court in Queensland heard on Monday that Perry started arguing with his relatives and became enraged when no one could tell him where the plant was.

Dylan Perry (pictured), 21, was visiting his mother's home in September when he realised a pot plant was missing

The man then grabbed a claw hammer and a sledgehammer from the shed.

He went in to his sister's bedroom and smashed her doll collection with the tools, before heading to the living room and busting a hole in the wall.

After being asked to leave the house, the irate man knocked a phone from someone's hand and broke the screen.

The man (pictured) became enraged and grabbed a claw hammer and a sledgehammer from the shed

The court acknowledged Perry's behaviour was out of character.

Perry was slapped with a $300 fine for wilful damage and domestic violence.

He was also fined an extra $150 because he didn't appear at the police station after being instructed to do so.

No conviction was recorded because the offence was deemed out of character.

authors: Charlotte Karp For Daily Mail Australia
